questions.text: Which of the following is not a trinucleotide repeat disorder? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontotemporal Dementia

 

Trinucleotide repeat disorders are a group of genetic conditions caused by the repetition of a specific set of three nucleotides within certain genes. These repeats can expand during DNA replication, leading to various diseases depending on the gene affected.

 

Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD) is generally not associated with trinucleotide repeat expansions. While some familial cases of FTD may be linked to mutations, such as hexanucleotide repeat expansions (six nucleotide repeats) in certain genes, it is not considered a trinucleotide repeat disorder like the other options provided.

 

Note –

 

Hexanucleotide repeat disorders:

 

  • One subtype of familial FTD (Frontotemporal Dementia) is being associated with hexanucleotide repeat expansions (c8 or c9 repeats)
  • Pick's disease (a variant of Frontotemporal Dementia), characterized by specific pathological findings such as Pick cells and sharp, knife-edge gyri.
  • Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) can be linked to hexanucleotide repeat expansions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fragile X syndrome: This is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by CGG repeats in the FMR1 gene.

 

Option B. Huntington Chorea: Also known as Huntington's disease, it is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by CAG repeats in the HTT gene. This primarily affects the caudate nucleus of the brain. It is associated with decreased levels of neurotransmitters like acetylcholine and GABA.

 

Option D. Myotonic dystrophy: This condition is due to a CTG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the DMPK gene. Features include the development of Christmas tree cataracts, gonadal atrophy, and early onset alopecia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontotemporal Dementia is not classified as a trinucleotide repeat disorder, distinguishing it from conditions like Fragile X syndrome, Huntington's disease, and Myotonic dystrophy, which are directly caused by trinucleotide repeat expansions.

choices.text: Islam needle

questions.text: A bone marrow biopsy was indicated in a patient with unexplained anemia and following needle was used to extract specimen. Identify the instrument: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Klima needle

 

The given instrument is a Klima needle used for bone marrow biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salah's needle: Salah's needle is another type of biopsy needle but is different in design and is not commonly used for bone marrow biopsies.

 

Option C. Jamshidi needle: The Jamshidi needle is also used for bone marrow biopsies and is one of the most commonly used tools for this purpose. However, it has a different appearance compared to the Klima needle.

 

Option D. Islam needle: This needle is used for certain types of biopsies but is not typically associated with bone marrow biopsy procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: It is a dematiaceous fungus
Infection can spread and involve underlying subcutaneous tissue, tendon, muscle or joints
Angioinvasion is common especially in people with hemolytic anemia
These bodies are formed by engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages

questions.text: A forest worker developed skin lesions over the forearm, which initially started as macules but then became nodules. Histology of the nodules shows the following findings. Which of the following is true regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a dematiaceous fungus

 

  • Chromoblastomycosis (CBM) is defined as a chronic cutaneous and subcutaneous fungal infection resulting from traumatic implantation of certain dematiaceous fungi through the skin.
  • The most frequent aetiological agents of CBM are the following species: Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Phialophora verrucosa and Cladophialophora carrionii.
  • The aetiological agents gain entrance through transcutaneous puncture wounds, usually by parts of plants.
  • In a typical manifestation the dermal lesions form cauliflower-like nodules. In the infected tissue, characteristic dark-colored, thick-walled, muriform cells i.e. sclerotic cells (Medlar bodies) are observed, which is a histopathological criterion for the diagnosis.
  • The aetiological agent (i.e. fungal fragment) gains entrance through transcutaneous puncture wounds. A primary lesion is represented by an erythematous papule or a warty growth, which gradually enlarges from the site of infection assuming various forms and sizes. The infection may occur anywhere on the body, however most frequently it affects limbs, especially feet and shins. Cases of buttock, trunk and face infection have also been reported. In more advanced stages of the disease dissemination may occur in the form of satellite lesions which arise from scratching autoinoculation and spread via the lymphatic system.
  • Treatment – Antifungal therapy with itraconazole or terbinafine. Surgical excision is the therapy of choice for small lesions.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Infection can spread and involve underlying subcutaneous tissue, tendon, muscle, or joints: This statement is more characteristic of eumycetoma, not chromoblastomycosis. Eumycetoma, caused by various fungal species, can invade deeper tissues including bone, leading to severe deformities.

 

Option C. Angioinvasion is common especially in people with hemolytic anemia: Angioinvasion is typically seen in infections caused by Aspergillus species, which can lead to invasive aspergillosis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. This is not a feature of chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option D. These bodies are formed by the engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages: The bodies seen in the histological image (Medlar bodies) are not formed by macrophage engulfment. They are a morphological form of the fungi present in the infected tissue, indicative of chromoblastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection characterized by the presence of dark-coloured, thick-walled sclerotic cells (Medlar bodies) in histological sections, resulting from traumatic implantation of dematiaceous fungi.

questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axilla. On microscopic examination of the skin scrapings, a red pigment-producing fungus with pencil-shaped macroconidia is seen. Which of the following is the most likely organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichophyton rubrum

 

The most likely organism based on the given history and image is Trichophyton rubrum. The colonies appear velvety and a deep red, non-diffusible pigment is seen when viewed from the reverse side of the colony. A few long and pencil-shaped macroconidia can be seen.

 

Trichophyton is a dermatophytic fungi that can infect hair, skin, or nails. Dermatophytes infect only the keratinized tissue and have keratinases that can digest keratin. There are 3 genera of dermatophytes:

 

  • ﻿﻿Trichophyton - The colonies may appear powdery, waxy, or velvety with pigmentation characteristics of different species.
  • ﻿﻿Epidermophyton - It infects the skin and nails, but not the hair. The colonies appear powdery and greenish-yellow.
  • Microsporum - It infects the hair and skin, but not the nails. The colonies may appear cotton-like, velvety, or powdery, with white to brown pigmentation.

 

Trichophyton rubrum causes tinea corporis. It results from the invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum, with lesions on the trunk and limbs. The lesions are usually well-defined and circular with a raised edge. It can also cause tinea pedis, tinea cruris, and onychomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The colonies of Trichophyton violaceus are very slow-growing, waxy with a violet/purple pigment. They have distorted hyphae, with conidia seen rarely.

 

 

Option C. Trichophyton tonsurans has a cream or yellowish colony with central furrows. Microconidia are abundantly seen. Thick-walled, irregular macroconidia are also seen.

 

 

Option D. Colonies of Trichophyton schoenleinii are smooth, waxy and brownish. Hyphal swellings are seen along with chlamydospores and favic chandelier.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichophyton rubrum is identified by its red pigment-producing, velvety colonies with characteristic pencil-shaped macroconidia, making it the causative agent of various dermatophyte infections including tinea corporis that could present with itching in the axilla. Understanding the colony morphology and microscopic features is crucial for accurate identification and appropriate treatment of dermatophyte infections.

questions.text: A lady presented with a pelvic mass which was hyperintense on T1-weighted image, hyperintense on T1-fat saturated image, and hypointense on T2-weighted image with T2 shading. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometrioma

 

The imaging findings described are characteristic of an endometrioma. Endometriomas are cystic ovarian lesions filled with old blood, often referred to as "chocolate cysts." On MRI, these lesions typically appear hyperintense on T1-weighted images due to the presence of subacute or chronic blood products. On T1-fat saturated images, the mass remains hyperintense, confirming that the hyperintensity is due to blood rather than fat. The hallmark feature of an endometrioma is the T2 shading sign, which refers to the gradual decrease in signal intensity on T2-weighted images due to repeated hemorrhage and layering of blood products within the cyst.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teratoma: Teratomas often contain fat, which would appear hyperintense on T1-weighted images but would become hypointense on T1-fat saturated sequences. The lack of T2 shading and persistence of T1 hyperintensity on fat saturation sequences make this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option C. Carcinoma ovary: Carcinoma of the ovary usually appears as a solid or complex cystic mass with variable signal characteristics. It does not typically present with T1 hyperintensity due to fat or blood nor does it show T2 shading.

 

Option D. Dysgerminoma: Dysgerminomas are solid ovarian tumors that do not exhibit hyperintensity on T1-weighted images or T2 shading. They usually appear as large, solid masses with homogeneous or slightly heterogeneous signal intensities on MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometriomas are characterized by T1 hyperintensity that persists on T1-fat saturated images and display the T2 shading sign, distinguishing them from other ovarian masses.

choices.text: It is quickly concentrated in the brain after IV administration
It shows the phenomenon of redistribution
It has a short duration of action due to rapid renal excretion

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding thiopentone except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It has a short duration of action due to rapid renal excretion

 

Explanation: 


Thiopentone's short duration of action is due to redistribution, not rapid renal excretion. Due to its high lipid solubility, it rapidly crosses the blood-brain barrier and enters the brain, causing quick onset of anesthesia. However, it then redistributes to other tissues (muscle and fat), leading to a rapid decrease in brain concentration and therefore a short duration of action. The drug remains in the body but is no longer in sufficient concentration in the brain to maintain anesthetic effects.

 

Other Options:


Option A. It is highly lipid-soluble drug : Correct. Thiopentone is highly lipid-soluble, which enables it to rapidly cross the blood-brain barrier.

 

Option B. It is quickly concentrated in the brain after IV administration : Correct. Due to its high lipid solubility, it rapidly enters the brain within seconds of IV administration.

 

Option C. It shows the phenomenon of redistribution : Correct. After initial brain concentration, thiopentone redistributes to other tissues, particularly muscle and fat.

 

Educational Objective: 


Thiopentone's short duration of action is due to redistribution to other tissues, not rapid renal excretion.

 

THIOPENTONE

 

  • T - Thiobarbiturates 
  • H - Hyperthyroidism 
  • I - Inadvertent intra-arterial injection causes vasospasm (treatment - flush with NS, heparin, lignocaine) 
  • O - pH 10.5 (alkaline) 
  • P - pH 
  • Porphyrias (C/I) 
  • Prolongation of QT interval 
  • E - Epilepsy
  • N - Neuroanesthesia (DOC) 
  • T - Termination of action- redistribution

questions.text: What is the maneuver depicted in the image given below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trotter’s method

 

The image shows Trotter's method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step to control epistaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epley's maneuver: Is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).

 

 

Option C. Mc Govern technique: A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway. It is used as an emergency management may be required in bilateral choanal atresia to provide an airway.

 

 

Option D. Valsalva maneuver: A technique where the patient forcefully exhales while keeping the mouth and nose closed. This increases intrathoracic pressure and is used in various medical situations, including adjusting ear pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trotter’s method is an effective first-line intervention for controlling epistaxis. It emphasizes maintaining an upright, forward-leaning posture to minimize blood swallowing and facilitate proper drainage, essential for patient comfort and safety during a nosebleed episode.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No.  183, 199

questions.text: The ureteric bud arises from which of the following embryological structures? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mesonephric duct

 

The ureteric bud arises from the mesonephric (or Wolffian) duct. The mesonephric duct is one of the primary structures in the early embryonic development of the urinary and reproductive systems. The ureteric bud's growth is stimulated by signals from the adjacent metanephrogenic blastema. The ureteric bud undergoes repeated branching to form the ureter, renal pelvis, calyces, and the collecting tubules of the kidneys.

 

  • The intermediate mesoderm is a specific type of mesoderm that is located between the paraxial mesoderm and lateral plate.
  • During development, it plays a crucial role in the formation of both the urogenital system and the reproductive system. It divides into two structures known as the genital ridge and nephrogenic cord.
  • The nephrogenic cord goes on to form three distinct structures - the pronephros, mesonephros, and metanephros. From the mesonephros, the ureteric bud develops and eventually fuses with the mesonephric duct.
  • The metanephros then proliferates around the ureteric bud, forming what is called the metanephric blastema. This ultimately gives rise to the definitive kidneys.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metanephros: The metanephros is the embryological structure that develops into the permanent kidney in humans. The metanephrogenic blastema (or metanephrogenic mesenchyme) is the tissue that surrounds the tip of the ureteric bud and interacts with it. Signals from the ureteric bud stimulate the metanephrogenic blastema to differentiate into the nephron components of the kidney (like the glomerulus, proximal tubule, loop of Henle, etc.). The metanephros is not the origin of the ureteric bud but rather interacts with it.

 

Option C. Pronephros: The pronephros is the most primitive of the three embryonic kidneys. It appears early in embryonic development but quickly degenerates and is non-functional in mammals. Its duct, the pronephric duct, eventually becomes the mesonephric duct when the mesonephros starts to develop. The pronephros itself does not give rise to the ureteric bud.

 

Option D. Genital sinus: The genital sinus is involved in the development of the lower parts of the reproductive system and parts of the urinary system. In females, it contributes to parts of the vagina, and in males, it contributes to parts of the urethra. It does not give rise to the ureteric bud.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

A. Dorsal views of the bladder showing the relation of the ureters and mesonephric ducts during development. Initially the ureters are formed by an outgrowth of the mesonephric duct

 

B-D. with time they assume a separate entrance into the urinary bladder

 

C and D. Note the trigone of the bladder formed by incorporation of the mesonephric ducts

questions.text: When is dilatation and curettage contraindicated? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelvic inflammatory disease

 

Explanation:

 

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) includes endometritis, salpingitis, oophoritis, and parametritis. Any interventions like dilatation and curettage (D&C) are contraindicated in active PID due to the risk of exacerbating the infection and causing further complications.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ectopic pregnancy: D&C is not contraindicated in ectopic pregnancy; however, it is not typically performed in its management as it does not provide any benefit for this condition.

 

Option C. Menstrual irregularities: D&C can be performed to obtain an endometrial biopsy in peri-menopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) if there are no other identifiable causes and if endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy is suspected.

 

Option D. Endometriosis: D&C is not usually performed solely for endometriosis unless there is an associated AUB that needs to be evaluated or treated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is contraindicated in active pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) due to the risk of spreading the infection

 

Ref: Page 168, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 25 yr G2P1 presents with heavy bleeding at 32 weeks. On examination, there is hypotension. The abdomen is tender and fetal parts not palpable. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abruptio placenta

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of a 25-year-old G2P1 woman presenting with heavy bleeding at 32 weeks of gestation, several key clinical features point towards a diagnosis of abruptio placenta.

 

Abruptio placenta, or placental abruption, is a condition where the placenta detaches from the uterine wall prematurely, leading to significant bleeding.

 

The critical signs here are:

 

  • Hypotension: This indicates significant blood loss, which can be seen in both placenta previa and placental abruption.
  • Tender abdomen: The tenderness of the abdomen is a hallmark of placental abruption due to the irritation and inflammation caused by the bleeding and the detached placenta.
  • Fetal parts not palpable: This is due to the tense and tender uterus, which is characteristic of placental abruption.

 

Abruptio placenta - Immediate management (delivery) is crucial to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

 

In contrast, placenta previa typically presents with painless bleeding, and the uterus is usually relaxed and non-tender. Placenta previa involves the placenta covering the cervical os, which can lead to painless bleeding without the tenderness seen in placental abruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: Usually presents with painless bleeding and a relaxed, non-tender uterus.

 

Option C. Show: Refers to the passage of a small amount of blood or mucus plug as labor begins, which does not cause significant bleeding or abdominal tenderness.

 

Option D. Rupture uterus: While it can cause significant bleeding and abdominal tenderness, it is less common and typically associated with a history of uterine surgery or trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleeding in Pregnancy after 28 weeks à is due to APH

 

2 MC causes are of APH are – Placenta Previa (Painless bleeding, nontender uterus) and Abruptio placenta (Painful bleeding, tense & tender uterus)

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals a positive Kernig's sign. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. A diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine

 

Cryptococcal meningitis is a serious fungal infection that commonly affects immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV. The standard first-line treatment for cryptococcal meningitis involves an induction therapy phase, typically with a combination of liposomal amphotericin B and flucytosine for at least 14 days. This regimen is effective in reducing the fungal burden and improving outcomes in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vancomycin: This antibiotic is used primarily for bacterial infections, particularly those caused by Gram-positive bacteria. It is not effective against fungal infections such as cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Option B. High dose fluconazole: While fluconazole is used in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis, it is generally used after the initial induction phase with amphotericin B and flucytosine. High dose fluconazole can be part of the consolidation or maintenance therapy.

 

Option C. Voriconazole: This antifungal is primarily used for infections caused by Aspergillus species and is not the preferred treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cryptococcal meningitis in HIV-positive patients, the first-line induction therapy is a combination of liposomal amphotericin B and flucytosine for at least 14 days.

questions.text: A 8-year-old child presents with sudden onset of high-grade fever, loss of consciousness and anemia, on examination the child is hypoglycemic and no focal neurological deficit is noted, what will be the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cerebral malaria


The clinical presentation described—sudden onset of high-grade fever, loss of consciousness, anemia, and hypoglycemia—is highly suggestive of cerebral malaria. Cerebral malaria is a severe and potentially fatal complication of infection with Plasmodium falciparum, the most dangerous of the malaria-causing parasites.

 

  • High fever and loss of consciousness: These are hallmark symptoms of cerebral malaria, reflecting the severe systemic response and potential brain involvement by the parasite.
  • Anemia: Anemia is common in malaria due to hemolysis of infected red blood cells.
  • Hypoglycemia: Hypoglycemia is a frequent complication in severe malaria, often exacerbated by the parasite's metabolism of glucose and the body's increased demand during fever and illness.
  • Absence of focal neurological deficits: This aligns with cerebral malaria, which typically presents with diffuse neurological symptoms rather than focal deficits.

 

Durck's granuloma is a pathological finding in cerebral malaria, characterized by localized areas of necrosis surrounded by a granulomatous reaction in the brain.

 

Durck granuloma seen in cerebral malaria: -

 

 

Treatment: Severe malaria, including cerebral malaria, should be treated with intravenous or intramuscular artesunate for at least 24 hours, followed by a complete course of an effective oral antimalarial regimen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TB meningitis: TB meningitis would typically present with chronic symptoms, such as a gradual onset of headache, fever, and neurological signs, along with CSF analysis showing low sugar, high protein, and lymphocytic predominance. The sudden onset and the specific symptoms described are more indicative of cerebral malaria.

 

Option C. Viral meningitis: While viral meningitis can present with fever and altered consciousness, it is generally less severe and does not typically cause the severe hypoglycemia and anemia seen in cerebral malaria.

 

Option D. Fungal meningitis: Fungal meningitis, such as cryptococcal meningitis, typically presents with more indolent symptoms, including headache, fever, and possibly altered mental status, but it is usually seen in immunocompromised individuals and lacks the acute, severe presentation described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:


Cerebral malaria is a severe complication of Plasmodium falciparum infection, characterized by sudden onset of high-grade fever, loss of consciousness, anemia, and hypoglycemia, without focal neurological deficits.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient came with complaints of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath. On examination, a mid-diastolic murmur was heard, and a prominent 'a' wave was found on JVP. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tricuspid stenosis

 

The presence of a mid-diastolic murmur and a prominent 'a' wave in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) are key indicators for diagnosing tricuspid stenosis.

 

Tricuspid Stenosis causes an obstruction to right ventricular inflow, which leads to an increase in right atrial pressure, reflected as a prominent 'a' wave in the JVP. The mid-diastolic murmur is due to the turbulent flow across the narrowed tricuspid valve during diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral Stenosis: While it can cause a diastolic murmur, it typically does not cause a prominent 'a' wave in the JVP unless there is secondary pulmonary hypertension affecting the right side of the heart.

 

Option C. Mitral Regurgitation: This would cause a holosystolic murmur and, if severe enough to cause pulmonary hypertension, may indirectly cause changes in the JVP, but it does not directly cause a prominent 'a' wave.

 

Option D. Tricuspid Regurgitation: This condition causes a large 'v' wave in the JVP due to backflow of blood into the right atrium during systole, not a prominent 'a' wave.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A prominent 'a' wave in JVP and a mid-diastolic murmur are indicative of tricuspid stenosis, a condition causing right ventricular inflow obstruction.

questions.text: Low serum copper levels attributed to ATP7A gene is due to: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Menke’s disease

 

  • Menke's disease, also known as Menkes Kinky Hair syndrome, is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene. This gene is crucial for the absorption and distribution of copper in the body. The mutation leads to reduced intestinal absorption of copper, resulting in low serum copper levels. This deficiency affects multiple systems, including neurodevelopment and connective tissue maintenance, often leading to severe developmental delay and life expectancy that rarely exceeds early childhood (Children die within 5 years). The condition is also associated with characteristic brittle, kinky hair, and growth retardation.
  • MCC: CVS-Aneurysmal dissection/Cardiac rupture

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: This is a liver disorder characterized by chronic jaundice and does not involve ATP7A or copper metabolism.

 

Option B. Wilson's disease: Although related to copper metabolism, Wilson's disease is due to mutations in the ATP7B gene, not ATP7A, leading to copper accumulation in tissues.

 

Option D. Gilbert's syndrome: This is a common hereditary condition that affects bilirubin metabolism, unrelated to copper levels or ATP7A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menke's disease is characterized by a genetic mutation in the ATP7A gene leading to poor copper absorption and severe systemic deficiencies, notable for its profound impact on early development and survival.

 

Reference - Harrison/Chap 333.

questions.text: Cowdry Type A inclusions are seen in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes simplex

 

Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles of Herpes Simplex infection

 

The classic Cowdry type A inclusion appears as a light purple, homogeneous intranuclear structure surrounded by a clear halo. The inclusions stain with antibodies to HS, permitting a rapid, specific diagnosis of HSV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Incorrect, as Rabies is associated with Negri bodies, which are specific cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum: Incorrect, as this condition is linked to Henderson-Peterson bodies, which are intracytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Option D. Adenovirus: Incorrect for Cowdry Type A inclusions; however, Cowdry type C basophilic inclusions are seen in Adenovirus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inclusion bodies produced in viral infection:

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive shown in the given image: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Female condom

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image is of a female condom. 
  • It is made of aa synthetic nitrile sheath with one flexible polyurethane ring at each end
  • One ring is open – lies outside the vagina.
  • The closed ring is fitted under the symphysis like a diaphragm
  • Male condoms should not be used simultaneously due to friction leading to slippage of condom or tearing
  • Also offers protection against STDs

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Male Condom:

 

 

Option C. Cervical diaphragm:

 

 

Option D. Cervical Cap:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The female condom is a synthetic nitrile sheath with one flexible polyurethane ring at each end, providing contraceptive protection and protection against STDs.

 

Ref: Page n 612, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Ito cells
Endothelial cells

questions.text: Which part of the liver stores vitamin A?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ito cells

 

Explanation

 

  • Ito cells are the cells that store vitamin A in the liver. These cells, also known as hepatic stellate cells, are located in the space of Disse, which is between the hepatocytes and the endothelial cells in the liver.
  • Ito cells play a role in liver function and pathology, and are involved in the regulation of extracellular matrix synthesis and degradation, as well as in the response to liver injury. They are also responsible for the storage and release of vitamin A in the liver.
  • Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages and Kupffer-Borowicz cells; are specialized macrophages located in the liver that form part of the mononuclear phagocyte system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatocytes: Incorrect, while hepatocytes are the main functional cells of the liver and perform numerous metabolic, synthetic, and detoxifying functions, they are not the primary storage sites for vitamin A.

 

Option C. Endothelial cells: Incorrect, these cells line the blood vessels of the liver and are involved in filtration and blood flow regulation within the organ, not in vitamin storage.

 

Option D. Kupffer cells: Incorrect, Kupffer cells are the liver's resident macrophages, involved in immune responses and the breakdown of red blood cells, not in storing vitamins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ito cells (hepatic stellate cells) are the primary storage sites for vitamin A in the liver. Their role extends beyond vitamin storage to include critical functions in the regulation of the extracellular matrix and the liver's response to injury.

choices.text: Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

questions.text: A farmer visits you with a foot swelling and multiple discharging sinuses in the lower limb. Microscopic examination of granules from the discharge was performed and is as shown in the image below. Based on this information, what can be concluded about this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

 

  • The clinical scenario, along with the presence of sulfur granules in the image, suggests a diagnosis of mycetoma. This condition can be caused by either bacteria (Actinomycetoma) or fungi (Eumycetoma).
  • Mycetoma typically occurs following a trauma, and individuals engaged in agricultural work are at higher risk of developing this condition.

 

 

Clinical features (GST):

 

  1. Grains,
  2. Sinuses,
  3. Tumefaction/swelling

 

The below image shows nodular lesions that have broken down to form draining sinuses with purulent discharge.

 

 

 

The discharge contains granules which are microcolonies of the causative organism. It is generally more invasive and can spread via the fascial planes (NOT Lymphatic) to the underlying muscle or bone. Dissemination is rare but can occur in lesions of the head and neck.

 

Treatment:

 

  1. Eumycetoma:
    • Antifungals (Itraconazole)
  2. Actinomycetoma:
    • Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin
    • Modified Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin + Rifampicin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. There is lymphocyte accumulation:

While lymphocytes can be present due to the chronic inflammatory nature of mycetoma, their accumulation is not a distinctive feature of this disease.

 

Option C. Undergoes lymphatic spread:

Mycetoma primarily spreads through contiguous tissue invasion rather than lymphatic spread. This is a feature that differentiates it from other infections like lymphatic filariasis.

 

Option D. Involves only superficial tissues:

This is incorrect because mycetoma can involve both superficial and deep structures, including skin, subcutaneous tissue, muscle, and even bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma can be caused by both bacteria and fungi, and is characterized by the presence of grains in discharging sinuses, often involving deep tissue structures beyond superficial tissues.

 

 

 

Reference –

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.75

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 401, 604, 605

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 689

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 1338, 1688

questions.text: Among the given options, murmur given in the image is associated with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mitral Regurgitation

 

The image provided indicates a murmur occurring between S1 and S2, which is described as a pan-systolic murmur. This type of murmur spans the entirety of systole.

 

Mitral Regurgitation produces a pan-systolic murmur due to the backward flow of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium throughout systole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic Regurgitation: Characterized by an early diastolic murmur due to backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle.

 

Option C. Mitral Stenosis: Characterized by a mid-diastolic murmur due to obstructed blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Option D. Aortic Stenosis: Characterized by an ejection systolic murmur due to turbulent blood flow across a narrowed aortic valve during systole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral regurgitation is associated with a pan-systolic murmur, which is present throughout the systole and heard between the S1 and S2 heart sounds.

questions.text: What type of stridor occur in croup?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biphasic stridor

 

Given the question is about croup, the correct answer is Biphasic stridor, because croup usually affects the subglottic region and can cause narrowing that affects both phases of breathing.

 

Biphasic stridor is heard during both inhalation and exhalation and indicates a narrowing at the level of the vocal cords or just below them in the subglottic region. This type of stridor is characteristic of croup, which typically affects the subglottic area of the larynx.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inspiratory stridor is a high-pitched sound that occurs during inhalation. It is commonly associated with conditions that cause narrowing of the upper airway above the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Expiratory stridor is a wheezing sound heard during exhalation and is less common. It suggests a problem lower in the respiratory tract, such as the bronchioles or smaller bronchi.

 

Option D. No stridor would mean that there is no abnormal airway sound, which would not be applicable in the context of a discussion about croup, which typically presents with stridor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Croup typically presents with biphasic stridor, which occurs during both inspiration and expiration, reflecting the subglottic airway narrowing characteristic of the condition.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs can increase glucose excretion in urine? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Empagliflozin

 

Explanation:

 

Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor.

 

Drugs in this class (such as empagliflozin, canagliflozin, and dapagliflozin) inhibit the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine (glycosuria). This helps lower blood glucose levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glimepiride: A sulfonylurea that stimulates insulin release from the pancreas.

 

Option B. Liraglutide: A GLP-1 receptor agonist that increases insulin secretion, slows gastric emptying, and promotes satiety.

 

Option C. Acarbose: An alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that delays carbohydrate absorption in the intestines, leading to increased excretion of undigested carbohydrates in the stools.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, increases glucose excretion in the urine by inhibiting the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in the kidneys.

questions.text: A patient presents at 18 weeks with low risk of trisomy on quadruple marker and high risk of NTD. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anomaly scan

 

The correct answer is Anomaly scan. This patient has a low risk of trisomy (such as Down syndrome) but a high risk of neural tube defects (NTD) based on the quadruple marker test. The quadruple marker test includes measurements of beta-hCG, unconjugated estriol, inhibin A, and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). A high level of AFP is associated with an increased risk of NTDs, such as spina bifida.

 

Given the elevated risk for NTDs, the most appropriate next step is an anomaly scan, specifically a targeted imaging for fetal anomaly (TIFA) scan. This ultrasound, typically performed between 18 and 20 weeks of gestation, has a high sensitivity (up to 99%) for detecting structural anomalies, particularly neural tube defects. The scan is a non-invasive way to assess the fetus for physical defects.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Amniocentesis: While amniocentesis can detect chromosomal abnormalities and some structural defects, it is invasive and carries a small risk of complications. Since the concern here is structural (NTD) rather than chromosomal, and the anomaly scan is highly effective and non-invasive, amniocentesis is not the first choice.

 

Option C. Chorionic villous sampling (CVS): CVS is another invasive procedure used for early genetic testing, usually performed in the first trimester. It is not useful at 18 weeks and is not the best test for detecting structural anomalies like NTDs.

 

Option D. NIPT (Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing): NIPT is a screening tool for chromosomal aneuploidies (like trisomy 21, 18, and 13). Since the patient already has a low risk of trisomy, NIPT is unnecessary and does not address the high risk of NTD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a high risk of neural tube defects identified by elevated alpha-fetoprotein on a quadruple marker test, the best next step is an anomaly scan (TIFA), which is highly effective in identifying structural fetal abnormalities, including NTDs

questions.text: A girl presents with short stature, webbed neck, thick calves, shield -shaped chest, swelling of the ankle, and increased carrying angle. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

 

The constellation of symptoms including short stature, webbed neck, thick calves, shield-shaped chest, swelling of the ankles, and increased carrying angle is suggestive of Turner syndrome.

 

Turner syndrome is caused by complete or partial X-chromosome monosomy. In phenotypic females, it causes hypogonadism. In females, it is the most common sex chromosome abnormality.

 

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome:

 

  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Streak ovaries, infertility, amenorrhea
  • Peripheral lymphedema at birth
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Pigmented nevi
  • Coarctation of aorta

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Down syndrome: (Trisomy 21) is characterized by intellectual disability, facial dysmorphism, and increased risk of certain medical conditions such as congenital heart defects and leukemia.

 

Option C. Patau syndrome: (Trisomy 13): characterised by severe intellectual disability, cleft lip/palate, polydactyly, microcephaly, congenital heart defects, and often leads to early infant mortality.

 

Option D. Edward syndrome: (Trisomy 18) characterised by severe intellectual disability, micrognathia (small jaw), clenched fists with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, congenital heart defects, and also typically results in early infant mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, shield-shaped chest, peripheral lymphedema, and increased carrying angle, among other physical manifestations. It is caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome in phenotypic females.

questions.text: Match the following cell types and the malignancy they are associated with: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c  

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of palpitations, shortness of breath, and dizziness. The child has no significant past medical history. On examination, the heart rate is 220 beats per minute, blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and the child appears anxious but is otherwise stable. An ECG confirms the diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). What is the initial recommended dose of adenosine for this child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.1 mg/kg

 

In the treatment of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) in children, the initial recommended dose of adenosine is 0.1 mg/kg administered intravenously. This dose is given as a rapid IV push and is often followed by a saline flush to ensure that the drug reaches the heart quickly. The maximum initial dose should not exceed 6 mg. If the first dose is ineffective, a second dose can be administered at 0.2 mg/kg, with a maximum dose of 12 mg.

 

Adenosine works by transiently blocking the atrioventricular (AV) node, which helps to terminate the reentrant circuit responsible for PSVT. It is the first-line treatment for PSVT due to its quick onset of action and short half-life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial recommended dose of adenosine for treating PSVT in children is 0.1 mg/kg, with a maximum dose of 6 mg. If the initial dose is ineffective, a higher dose of 0.2 mg/kg may be administered.

questions.text: The vector shown in the image below transmits which of the following organism? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orientia tsutsugamushi

 

  • The picture depicts a trombiculid mite, known for transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi.

 

SCRUB TYPHUS (ORIENTIA)

 

  • Caused by → Orientia tsutsugamushi
  • Vector → Trombiculid mites (Leptotrombidium)
  • Chiggerosis → Among all stages of mite, larvae (called chiggers) are only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Clinical manifestations
    • Eschar (at the site of bite)
    • Regional lymphadenopathy
    • Maculopapular rash
  • DOC → Doxycycline

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kyasanur forest disease: Kyasanur forest disease is vector borne disease caused by hard tick.

 

 

Option C. Chandipura virus: Chandipura virus is vector borne disease transmitted by sandfly

 

 

Option D. Anaplasma: Anaplasma is a tick-borne disease affecting ruminants, dogs, and horses, and is caused by Anaplasma bacteria. Mainly transmitted by Ixodes ticks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The trombiculid mite, particularly in its larval stage called a chigger, transmits Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus.

questions.text: Graft rejection is seen maximum with which organ? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lungs

 

Explanation:

 

Among solid organ transplants, lungs have the highest risk of rejection, followed by the heart, kidneys, and liver. This is due to the lungs' constant exposure to the external environment and their rich supply of blood and lymphatic vessels, which increases the likelihood of the recipient's immune system encountering and reacting to foreign antigens from the transplanted lung tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart has the second-highest risk of rejection after lungs.

 

Option C. Intestine transplantation was not mentioned in the question stem or the explanation.

 

Option D. Kidney has a lower risk of rejection compared to lungs and heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of organ rejection risk from highest to lowest is:

 

  1. Lungs (maximum chances of rejection)
  2. Heart 
  3. Kidneys
  4. Liver

questions.text: What is the antigen present in the recombinant HPV vaccine?  (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) L1

 

Explanation:

 

The recombinant HPV vaccine primarily includes the L1 protein, which self-assembles into virus-like particles, providing the basis for immune recognition without causing the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E1 + E2: E1 and E2 are early viral proteins, not included in vaccines due to their role in viral replication.

 

Option B. E6 + E7: E6 and E7 are proteins involved in oncogenesis, not appropriate for vaccine development.

 

Option D. L2: L2 is also a capsid protein but not the primary antigen used in current HPV vaccines.

 

Educational objective:

 

The L1 protein of HPV forms the basis of the recombinant HPV vaccine, effectively stimulating an immune response by mimicking the virus structure.

questions.text:
Which of the following cannot cross the placenta? (NEET PG 2018)

 

  1. Iron
  2. Albumin
  3. Immunoglobulin M
  4. Immunoglobulin G
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 and 3

 

High molecular weight substances such as proteins (e.g., albumin, IgM, IgA) cannot cross the placenta.

 

Other Options:

 

1: Iron can cross the placenta via active transport mechanisms, making this option incorrect.

 

4: Immunoglobulin G (IgG) can cross the placenta through endocytosis and exocytosis mechanisms, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High molecular weight substances such as albumin and Immunoglobulin M (IgM) cannot cross the placenta.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male underwent surgery for rectal prolapse, and a postoperative image was obtained. Can you identify the procedure that was most likely performed on the patient from the given image below ? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiersch stitch

 

  • The postoperative image suggests the use of Thiersch wiring for rectal prolapse.
  • Thiersch's wiring involves placing a steel wire or a silastic/nylon tape around the anal canal.
  • It is now rarely done due to postoperative problems such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy: A minimally invasive surgical technique used to treat internal hemorrhoids by repositioning prolapsed tissue back to its normal anatomical position with a circular stapling device. This procedure does not align with the provided image of Thiersch wiring.

 

Option B. Well's procedure: An abdominal procedure for rectal prolapse that involves repositioning and attaching the rectum to the sacrum using sutures, often reinforced with mesh. This technique does not correspond to the image provided, which clearly shows a perineal approach with wiring.

 

Option D. Altemeier repair: A perineal approach to resect and anastomose the prolapsed rectum. While Altemeier repair is a perineal procedure, it involves resection and anastomosis rather than the placement of a circumferential wire around the anus, as seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thiersch's procedure, involving the placement of a wire or tape around the anal canal, is used in managing rectal prolapse but is now infrequently performed due to associated complications such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

questions.text: True regarding Oral Cholera vaccine ‘Sanchol’ is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Bivalent with 2 doses

 

The oral cholera vaccine ‘Sanchol’ is a bivalent vaccine designed to protect against serotypes O1 and O139 of the cholera bacteria. It is administered as 2 liquid doses for individuals aged 1 year and older, with a booster dose recommended every 2 years. The vaccine does not contain subunit B antitoxin; hence it does not require a buffer during administration.

 

Educational Objective:


CHOLERA ORAL VACCINES:

 

  •  Dukoral (WC-rBS): Monovalent, V cholera O1 plus Recombinant Toxin B subunit.
    • 2 doses (if age ≥6 years) and booster once/ 2 years
    • 3 doses (if age b/w 2-5 years) and booster dose once per 6 months.
  •  Sanchol and mORCVAX: Bivalent, Serogroups O1 & O139, No toxin B subunit, No buffer required. 2 liquid doses after the age of 1 year and booster after 2 years.
  • Euvichol: it is just like Sanchol. Bivalent with 2 doses.

questions.text: A patient reports to the OPD with complaints of fatigue and pallor. Investigations indicated hemoglobin of 5.9 g/dL, increased RDW, increased total iron binding capacity, and low ferritin. The peripheral smear shows microcytosis. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with symptoms of fatigue and pallor, which are common findings in anemia. The investigations reveal a low hemoglobin level of 5.9 g/dL, indicating the presence of anemia. The increased red cell distribution width (RDW) suggests anisocytosis, or variation in the size of red blood cells.

 

The increased total iron binding capacity (TIBC) and low ferritin levels indicate a deficiency in iron stores. Additionally, the peripheral smear shows microcytosis, which means the presence of small, hypochromic red blood cells. These findings are characteristic of iron deficiency anemia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemolytic anemia is incorrect because these patients typically have an increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV) due to the premature destruction of red blood cells and the release of larger, immature cells into the circulation.

 

Option C. Megaloblastic anemia is incorrect because it is characterized by the presence of large, macrocytic red blood cells, rather than the small, microcytic cells seen in this case.

 

Option D. Sideroblastic anemia is incorrect because it is typically associated with elevated ferritin levels due to increased iron storage, whereas this patient has low ferritin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by low hemoglobin, increased RDW, increased TIBC, low ferritin, and the presence of microcytic red blood cells on peripheral smear.

questions.text: Diagnose the X-ray as shown below: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteosarcoma


Osteosarcoma is a type of malignant bone tumor that typically shows characteristic radiographic features such as the "sunburst" or "sun ray" appearance, which is caused by the tumor's aggressive growth pattern. In addition to this, Codman’s triangle may be visible, which occurs when the tumor lifts the periosteum off the bone, forming a triangular area of new bone formation. The lower end of the femur is a common site for osteosarcoma, as well as other long bones in the body.

 

In the provided X-rays, the sun ray appearance is clearly visible, making osteosarcoma the correct diagnosis in this case.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondroblastoma: This tumor typically presents with calcifications in the epiphyseal (end) regions of bones, particularly in the upper end of the humerus. However, chondroblastoma does not present with a sun ray appearance.

 

 

Option B. Chondrosarcoma: This is another malignant tumor, but it primarily affects the upper end of the femur or pelvis. The X-ray for chondrosarcoma typically shows dense calcifications, but not the sun ray pattern associated with osteosarcoma.

 

 

Option C. Ewing's sarcoma: This tumor often presents with a diaphyseal (shaft) lesion in long bones and can cause an "onion-skin" appearance due to the layered periosteal reaction. It does not exhibit the sun ray pattern seen in osteosarcoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

The sun ray appearance and Codman’s triangle in X-rays are key indicators of osteosarcoma, especially in the lower end of long bones like the femur.

questions.text: A child presented with difficulty in walking. The wrist radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rickets

 

RICKETS

 

  • Osteoid matrix is secreted at normal rate but the mineralization is decreased (i.e. decrease in mineral apposition rate).
  • This leads to increased osteoid maturation time (mineralization).
  • Osteoid is increased in thickness, volume and total surface area.
  • Bone tissue throughout skeleton is incompletely calcified and therefore softened.
  • Rickets refers to condition where it occurs before closure of growth plates so that abnormalities of skeletal growth are superimposed.
  • Pathology:
    • Osteoid is laid down irregularly with widened osteoid seams and osteoid islets may even persist down into the diaphysis.
    • The new trabeculae are thin and weak (as bundle of collagen fibers instead of running parallel to Haversian canal, coarse perpendicularly) and with joint loading, the juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and ‘cup-shaped'.
  • Clinical features:
    • Generalized muscular hypotonia of an unknown mechanism is observed in most patients with clinical (as opposed to biochemical and radiographic) signs of rickets.
    • Craniotabes (areas of thinning and softening of bones of the skull) manifests early in infants with vitamin D deficiency, although this feature may not be present in infants, especially those born prematurely.
    • If rickets occurs at a later age, thickening of the skull develops. This produces frontal bossing and delays the closure of the anterior fontanelle.
    • In the long bones, laying down of uncalcified osteoid at the metaphyses leads to spreading of those areas, producing knobby deformity, which is visualized on radiography as cupping and flaring of the metaphyses.

 

 

  • Weight bearing produces deformities such as bow-legs and knock-knees.
  • In the chest, knobby deformities result in the so-called rachitic rosary along the costochondral junctions. The weakened ribs pulled by muscles also produce flaring over the diaphragm, which is known as Harrison groove. The sternum may be pulled into a pigeon-breast deformity.

 

 

  • In more severe instances in children older than 2 years, vertebral softening leads to kyphoscoliosis. The ends of the long bones demonstrate the same knobby thickening.
  • At the ankle, palpation of the tibial malleolus gives the impression of a double epiphysis (Marfan sign).

 

 

  • Because the softened long bones may bend, they may fracture on one side of the cortex (i.e., greenstick fracture).

 

  • X-rays:
    • Metaphyseal fraying and splaying along with cupping, thickening and widening of growth plate.
    • Bowing of legs and deformities occur at later stages.
  • Investigations:
    • Serum calcium, phosphate, 25-OH vitamin D are reduced.
    • Increased ALP and diminished urinary excretion of calcium.
  • Treatment:
  • Treatment with vitamin D (400-1000 IU per day) and calcium supplements are usually effective.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Osteomalacia. Often referred to as "soft bone disease," is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by the inadequate mineralization of bone tissue. There is adult onset of bone softening and muscle weakness. This condition results from a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, weakening and softening bones. Symptoms are non-specific and may include low back and thigh pain, proximal muscle weakness and wasting; Myalgia and arthralgia; Muscle spasms; waddling gait; Spinal, limb, or pelvic deformities; Aching bone pain aggravated by activity and weight-bearing; Increased falls; Hypocalcemic seizures or tetany. Triradiate pelvis, protrusion acetabular (acetabulum protrudes into pelvis due to bone softening. When bilateral, it is called as Otto Pelvis), pseudofracture are seen on x-ray. There is waddling gait due to muscular weakness.

 

 

A. Triradiate pelvis; B. Protrusio acetabuli

 

Option B. Osteogenesis imperfecta. It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative and qualitative defect in type I collagen formation. There is alteration in the structural integrity, or a reduction in the total amount of type I collagen. Most common cause of multiple fractures in childhood. It is inherited from a parent in autosomal dominant (AD) fashion, or may occur as spontaneous mutation, or, rarely as autosomal recessive (AR) trait. The defining clinical feature is osteopenia, causing repeated propensity to fracture, generally after minor trauma and often without much pain or swelling. According to the severity of disease, fractures may occur in uterus, at birth, or after birth prior to or after walking age. Lower limb fractures are more common than upper limb. Femur is commonest bone fractured followed by tibia. Hyperlaxity of ligaments, with resultant hypermobility of joint is common. Blue/gray sclera due to uveal pigment visible through thin collagen layer. Deafness due to otosclerosis/pressure on auditory nerve. Dentinogenesis imperfect/crumbling of teeth i.e., deciduous and permanent teeth break easily and become prone to carries. Lower incisors severely affected. Skin becomes thin and translucent. Muscles are hypotonic due to multiple fractures and deformities. Wormian bones (detached portions of primary ossification centers of adjacent membrane bones) are seen in skull X-ray. Ring-shaped epiphysis is seen. Skeleton: White crumpled-bone shaped not maintained.

 

 

Option D. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone which leads to cortical widening and contributes to the deformity.

 

 

The diagnostic histological feature is irregular area of lamellar bone fitting together like a jigsaw with randomly distributed cement lines. It either occurs in one bone (monostotic) or multiple bones (polyostotic).

 

 

Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. Pain is most common presenting symptom. Limb looks bent and feels thick, and skin is unduly warm due to high vascularity. X-ray shows deformity, enlargement or expansion of bone with cortical thickening, coarsening of trabecular markings and lytic and sclerotic changes. Blade of grass lesion is seen.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The image given in the question shows cupping, fraying and splaying of metaphysis of the distal end of both the radius and ulna, which are characteristic of rickets, alongwith walking difficulty.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has activity against both HBV and HIV? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tenofovir

 

Tenofovir is an antiretroviral medication that is effective against both HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) and HBV (Hepatitis B Virus). It is a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that works by inhibiting the action of reverse transcriptase, an enzyme crucial for the replication of both HIV and HBV. Tenofovir is commonly used in the treatment of HIV infection and is also a key component in the management of chronic hepatitis B, particularly in patients co-infected with HIV and HBV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abacavir: This is another NRTI used in the treatment of HIV but it does not have significant activity against HBV.

 

Option C. Nevirapine: A non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) used in the treatment of HIV, with no activity against HBV.

 

Option D. Enfuvirtide: A fusion inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV that works by preventing the virus from entering the cells. It does not have activity against HBV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs effective against both HIV and HBV coinfection: Lamivudine, Emtricitabine and Tenofovir

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents with metastatic breast cancer. She has previously undergone treatment with surgery, radiation, and multiple lines of chemotherapy, but her disease has progressed. Genetic testing reveals a BRCA1 mutation, indicating an impaired DNA repair mechanism. Her cancer is classified as HER2-negative and hormone receptor-positive. Given the genetic findings, her oncologist considers using a therapy that targets the PARP enzyme to exploit the DNA repair vulnerability of her cancer cells. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate to prescribe as a PARP inhibitor in this patient? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rucaparib

 

Explanation: 


Rucaparib is a PARP (Poly ADP-Ribose Polymerase) inhibitor. PARP inhibitors work by blocking DNA repair mechanisms in cancer cells. In patients with BRCA mutations (who already have impaired DNA repair), PARP inhibition leads to synthetic lethality and cell death. The name helps identify PARP inhibitors as they end in "parib" (from Poly ADP-Ribose Polymerase inhibitor).

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Palbociclib: Incorrect. This is a cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) 4/6 inhibitor used in hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. While it might be useful in this patient's case, it is not a PARP inhibitor.

 

Option C. Vorinostat: Incorrect. This is a histone deacetylase inhibitor used in certain hematologic malignancies, not a PARP inhibitor.

 

Option D. Ustekinumab: Incorrect. This is a monoclonal antibody against interleukins used in psoriasis and other autoimmune conditions, not a PARP inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:


PARP inhibitors (drugs ending in "parib") are particularly effective in cancers with BRCA mutations due to their mechanism of synthetic lethality in cells with impaired DNA repair.
 

Breast Cancer

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fluent aphasia

 

The posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus is where Wernicke's area is located, which is crucial for language comprehension. Lesions in this area lead to Wernicke's aphasia, which is a type of fluent aphasia. Patients with this type of aphasia exhibit fluent but often meaningless speech and have significant difficulties in understanding spoken language. Their speech is typically characterized by normal flow and articulation but includes nonsensical phrases and incorrect word substitutions (neologisms).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-fluent aphasia: This type of aphasia, typically associated with damage to Broca’s area in the frontal lobe, results in slow, labored speech and struggle in forming words, though comprehension often remains intact.

 

Option C. Anomic aphasia: In anomic aphasia, the person can speak fluently and understand speech but has difficulty naming objects and words, typically not linked to damage in the superior temporal gyrus.

 

Option D. Conduction aphasia: This arises from damage to the arcuate fasciculus, the brain structure that connects Wernicke's area to Broca’s area. It is characterized by fluent speech with frequent errors, good comprehension, but poor repetition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Regions anterior to the central sulcus are motor areas and posterior are sensory areas. Hence temporal gyrus involvement causes a fluent aphasia.

 

 

Reference - KV Krishna Das textbook of Medicine 5th edition

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient after receiving haloperidol developed torticollis and dystonia. What will be the best drug in this situation? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Give benzhexol (anticholinergic)

 

Explanation

 

The patient has developed extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), which are side effects commonly associated with antipsychotic medications like haloperidol. EPS can include dystonia (muscle contractions causing twisting and repetitive movements or abnormal postures) and torticollis (a type of dystonia involving the neck muscles).

 

Benzhexol, also known as trihexyphenidyl, is an anticholinergic drug that is effective in treating EPS, including acute dystonic reactions. Anticholinergics help to balance the neurotransmitters in the brain, thereby reducing the symptoms of EPS.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Increase haloperidol dose: This would likely worsen the EPS.

 

Option B. Change haloperidol to clozapine: While clozapine has a lower risk of EPS, this is not an immediate treatment for the acute dystonia.

 

Option D. Change haloperidol to fluphenazine: Fluphenazine, like haloperidol, is a potent dopamine receptor blocker and would likely exacerbate the EPS.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The immediate treatment for drug-induced dystonia is the administration of anticholinergic drugs like benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl).

questions.text:
Substances and the type of transport across a membrane are given below, choose the correct combination: (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Oxygen: simple diffusion
  2. Glucose: Facilitated diffusion
  3. Sodium: voltage-gated channel
  4. Sodium: Secondary active transport
  5. Calcium: Active transport
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 are correct

 

1. Oxygen: Simple diffusion - It moves from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration across the lipid bilayer of the cell membrane. No transport protein is required.

 

2. Glucose: Facilitated diffusion - It moves from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration with the help of glucose transporters. No energy is required.

 

3. Sodium: Voltage-gated channel - It moves down the electrochemical gradient through the voltage-gated channels. These channels are opened by a change in the membrane potential.

 

4. Sodium: Secondary active transport - It moves against the electrochemical gradient with the help of a co-transporter protein. The energy is provided by the electrochemical gradient of another molecule such as sodium or hydrogen ions.

 

5. Calcium: Active transport - It moves against the concentration gradient with the help of ATP-powered pumps. These pumps maintain a low intracellular calcium concentration compared to the extracellular environment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxygen moves by simple diffusion without a transport protein. Glucose uses facilitated diffusion with transporters. Sodium uses both voltage-gated channels and secondary active transport. Calcium uses active transport via ATP-powered pumps.

choices.text: Skin lesions and bruises of various ages are seen on the body
It occurs due to the tendency of a child to fall repeatedly
The syndrome is a result of gun injuries

questions.text: Identify the true statement from the following about battered baby syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Skin lesions and bruises of various ages are seen on the body

 

Battered child syndrome is defined as the collection of injuries sustained by a child as a result of repeated mistreatment or beating. If a child's injuries indicate intentional trauma or appear to be more severe than could reasonably be expected to result from an accident, battered child syndrome should be suspected.

 

Skin lesions and bruises of different ages (from young to old) are a classical feature of a child with battered baby syndrome.

 

Skeletal survey helps in identifying bone injuries in Battered Baby syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It occurs due to the tendency of a child to fall repeatedly: False: While children do fall frequently, the pattern and severity of injuries in battered child syndrome are inconsistent with typical childhood falls and accidents.

 

Option C. Stab wounds are obvious: False: Stab wounds are not a common feature of battered child syndrome. The syndrome primarily involves bruises, fractures, and other signs of physical abuse.

 

Option D. The syndrome is a result of gun injuries: False: Battered child syndrome is not characterized by gun injuries. It involves repeated physical abuse, leading to various types of trauma, particularly bruises and fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battered child syndrome is characterized by the presence of skin lesions and bruises of different ages, indicating repeated and ongoing physical abuse.
